content:
SchemaNameCollection Class

Definition

Contains a list of the schema names that the stem.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntries.SchemaFilter* property of a DirectoryEntries object can use.

In this Article

public class SchemaNameCollection : System.Collections.IList
Inheritance
System.Object
SchemaNameCollection

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
Equals(Object,Object)
GetHashCode()
GetType()
MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
ToString()

Properties

Count

The Count property gets the number of objects in this collection.

public int Count { get; }
Value
Int32

The number of objects in this collection.

Item(Int32)

Gets or sets the object that exists at a specified index.

public string this[int index] { get; set; }
index
Int32

The zero-based index into the collection.

Value
String

The object that exists at the specified index.

Remarks

In C#, this property is the indexer for the SchemaNameCollection class.

In JScript, you can use the default indexed properties defined by a type, but you cannot explicitly define your own. However, specifying the expando attribute on a class automatically provides a default indexed property whose type is Object and whose index type is String.

Methods

Add(String)

Appends a specified schema name to this collection.

public int Add (string value);
value
String

The schema name to add to this collection.

Returns
Int32

The zero-based index of the specified property value. If the object is not found, the return value is -1.

AddRange(SchemaNameCollection)

Appends a set of specified schema names to this collection.

public void AddRange (System.DirectoryServices.SchemaNameCollection value);
value
SchemaNameCollection

A SchemaNameCollection that contains the schema names to add.

AddRange(String[])

Appends a set of specified schema names to this collection.

public void AddRange (string[] value);
value
String[]

An array of type String that contains the schema names to add.

Clear()

Removes all objects from this collection.

public void Clear ();

Contains(String)

Determines whether this collection contains a specified schema name.

public bool Contains (string value);
value
String

The schema name to search for.

Returns
Boolean

The return value is true if the specified property belongs to this collection; otherwise, false.

CopyTo(String[],Int32)

Copies the schema names from this collection to an array, starting at a particular index of the array.

public void CopyTo (string[] stringArray, int index);
stringArray
String[]

An array of type String that receives this collection's schema names.

index
Int32

The zero-based array index at which to begin copying the schema names.

GetEnumerator()

Returns an enumerator that you can use to iterate through this collection.

public System.Collections.IEnumerator GetEnumerator ();
Returns
IEnumerator

An enumerator that you can used to iterate through this collection.

IndexOf(String)

Determines the index of a specified schema name in this collection.

public int IndexOf (string value);
value
String

The schema name to search for.

Returns
Int32

The zero-based index of the specified schema name, or -1 if the schema name was not found in the collection.

Insert(Int32,String)

Inserts a schema name into this collection at a specified index.

public void Insert (int index, string value);
index
Int32

The zero-based index into the collection at which to insert the schema name.

value
String

The schema name to insert into this collection.

Remarks

If the index parameter equals the number of items in the collection, this method appends the value to the end of the collection.

Remove(String)

Removes a specified schema name from this collection.

public void Remove (string value);
value
String

The schema name to remove.

RemoveAt(Int32)

Removes the schema name that is at a specified index from this collection.

public void RemoveAt (int index);
index
Int32

The zero-based index of the schema name to remove.

Exceptions
IndexOutOfRangeException

The zero-based index is either less than zero or equal to the size of the collection.

Explicit Interface Implementations

ICollection.CopyTo(Array,Int32)

Copies the elements of the ICollection to an Array, starting at a particular Array index.

void ICollection.CopyTo (Array array, int index);
array
Array

The one-dimensional Array that is the destination of the elements copied from ICollection. The Array must have zero-based indexing.

index
Int32

The zero-based index in array at which copying begins.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

array is null.

ArgumentOutOfRangeException

index is less than zero.

ArgumentException

array is multidimensional.

-or-

The number of elements in the source ICollection is greater than the available space from index to the end of the destination array.

InvalidCastException

The type of the source ICollection cannot be cast automatically to the type of the destination array.

ICollection.IsSynchronized

Gets a value indicating whether access to the ICollection is synchronized (thread safe).

bool System.Collections.ICollection.IsSynchronized { get; }
Returns
Boolean

true if access to the ICollection is synchronized (thread safe); otherwise, false.

Remarks

SyncRoot returns an object, which can be used to synchronize access to the ICollection.

Most collection classes in the System.Collections namespace also implement a Synchronized method, which provides a synchronized wrapper around the underlying collection.

Enumerating through a collection is intrinsically not a thread-safe procedure. Even when a collection is synchronized, other threads can still modify the collection, which causes the enumerator to throw an exception. To guarantee thread safety during enumeration, you can either lock the collection during the entire enumeration or catch the exceptions resulting from changes made by other threads.

[Visual Basic, C#]

The following example shows how to lock the collection using the SyncRoot during the entire enumeration: 

ICollection myCollection = new ICollection();  
  lock(myCollection.SyncRoot) {  
  foreach (Object item in myCollection) {  
  // Insert your code here.  
  }  
 }  

Dim myCollection As New ICollection()  
 Dim item As Object  
 SyncLock myCollection.SyncRoot  
  For Each item In myCollection  
  ' Insert your code here.  
  Next item  
 End SyncLock

ICollection.SyncRoot

Gets an object that can be used to synchronize access to the ICollection.

object System.Collections.ICollection.SyncRoot { get; }
Returns
System.Object

An object that can be used to synchronize access to the ICollection.

Remarks

For collections with an underlying store is not publicly available, the expected implementation is to return the current instance. Note that the pointer to the current instance might not be sufficient for collections that wrap other collections; those should return the underlying collection's SyncRoot property.

Most collection classes in the System.Collections namespace also implement a Synchronized method, which provides a synchronized wrapper around the underlying collection. However, derived classes can provide their own synchronized version of the collection using the SyncRoot property. The synchronizing code must perform operations on the SyncRoot of the collection, not directly on the collection. This ensures proper operation of collections that are derived from other objects. Specifically, it maintains proper synchronization with other threads that might be simultaneously modifying the collection instance.

In the absence of a Synchronized method on a collection, the expected usage for SyncRoot looks like this: 

ICollection MyCollection =...  
 lock(MyCollection.SyncRoot) {  
  // Some operation on the collection, which is now thread safe.  
 }  

Dim myCollection as New ICollection()  
 SyncLock myCollection.SyncRoot  
  ' Some operation on the collection, which is now thread safe.  
 End SyncLock

Enumerating through a collection is intrinsically not a thread-safe procedure. Even when a collection is synchronized, other threads can still modify the collection, which causes the enumerator to throw an exception. To guarantee thread safety during enumeration, you can either lock the collection during the entire enumeration or catch the exceptions resulting from changes made by other threads.

[Visual Basic, C#]

The following example shows how to lock the collection using the SyncRoot during the entire enumeration: 

ICollection myCollection = new ICollection();  
 lock(myCollection.SyncRoot) {  
  foreach (Object item in myCollection) {  
  // Insert your code here.  
  }  
 }  

Dim myCollection As New ICollection()  
 Dim item As Object  
 SyncLock myCollection.SyncRoot  
  For Each item In myCollection  
  ' Insert your code here.  
  Next item  
 End SyncLock

IList.Add(Object)

Adds an item to the list.

int IList.Add (object value);
value
System.Object

The item to add to the list.

Returns
Int32

The position into which the new item was inserted.

IList.Contains(Object)

Determines whether the list contains a specified value.

bool IList.Contains (object value);
value
System.Object

The value to locate in the list.

Returns
Boolean

true if the value is found in the list, otherwise false.

Remarks

Starting with the .NET Framework 2.0, this method uses the Equals and CompareTo methods of the objects in the collection to determine whether item exists. In the earlier versions of the .NET Framework, this determination was made by using the Equals and CompareTo methods of the item parameter on the objects in the collection.

IList.IndexOf(Object)

Determines the index of a specified item in the list.

int IList.IndexOf (object value);
value
System.Object

The item to locate in the list.

Returns
Int32

The index of value if found in the list; otherwise, -1.

Remarks

Starting with the .NET Framework 2.0, this method uses the Equals and CompareTo methods of the objects in the collection to determine whether item exists. In the earlier versions of the .NET Framework, this determination was made by using the Equals and CompareTo methods of the item parameter on the objects in the collection.

IList.Insert(Int32,Object)

Inserts an item to the list at the specified index.

void IList.Insert (int index, object value);
index
Int32

The zero-based index at which value should be inserted.

value
System.Object

The item to insert into the list.

Remarks

If index equals the number of items in the list, then value is appended to the end.

In collections of contiguous elements, such as lists, the elements that follow the removed element move up to occupy the vacated spot. If the collection is indexed, the indexes of the elements that are moved are also updated.

IList.IsFixedSize

Gets a value indicating whether the IList has a fixed size.

bool System.Collections.IList.IsFixedSize { get; }
Returns
Boolean

true if the IList has a fixed size; otherwise, false.

Remarks

A collection with a fixed size does not allow the addition or removal of elements after the collection is created, but it allows the modification of existing elements.

IList.IsReadOnly

Gets a value indicating whether the IList is read-only.

bool System.Collections.IList.IsReadOnly { get; }
Returns
Boolean

true if the IList is read-only; otherwise, false.

Remarks

A collection that is read-only does not allow the addition, removal, or modification of elements after the collection is created.

IList.Item(Int32)

Gets or sets the element at the specified index.

object System.Collections.IList.Item[int index] { get; set; }
index
Int32

The zero-based index of the element to get or set.

Returns
System.Object

The element at the specified index.

Exceptions
ArgumentOutOfRangeException

index is not a valid index in the IList.

NotSupportedException

The property is set and the IList is read-only.

Remarks

This property provides the ability to access a specific element in the collection by using the following syntax: myCollection[index].

IList.Remove(Object)

Removes the first occurrence of a specific value from the list.

void IList.Remove (object value);
value
System.Object

The value to remove from the list.

Remarks

In collections of contiguous elements, such as lists, the elements that follow the removed element move up to occupy the vacated spot. If the collection is indexed, the indexes of the elements that are moved are also updated.
